0	0	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-poll-idUSKCN1272F1	Clinton leads Trump by 5 points in presidential race: Reuters/Ipsos poll	"
By Chris Kahn
| NEW YORK
NEW YORK Democratic presidential candidate Hillary Clinton leads Republican rival Donald Trump by 5 percentage points among likely voters
column2: roughly the same advantage she has held over the past several weeks
column3: according to the Reuters/Ipsos national tracking poll released Friday.The Sept. 30-Oct. 6 opinion poll showed that 43 percent of likely voters supported Clinton while 38 percent supported Trump. Clinton has consistently led Trump by 4-6 points in every weekly poll since the beginning of September.During this period
column4: the candidates faced off in the most-watched presidential debate in history - a matchup that a majority of Americans believed Clinton won. The New York Times also released portions of Trump's 1995 tax returns that showed the celebrity real estate developer had reported a loss that was big enough to have allowed him to avoid paying personal taxes for a number of years.Clinton and Trump will meet again in their second debate on Sunday night
column5: which will be in a town hall format
column6: with the Nov. 8 election fast approaching.At this point in 2012
column7: the race was tighter between Democratic President Barack Obama and Republican challenger Mitt Romney: Obama led Romney by less than 2 percentage points among likely voters in the Reuters/Ipsos poll during the first week of October. The incumbent eventually won the 2012 election by nearly the same margin in the popular vote.

column1: This year
column2: however
column3: both candidates appear to have a bigger opportunity to shake up the race and improve their numbers in the final weeks
column4: given that a larger proportion of the electorate appears to be uncommitted. When asked in the poll
column5: roughly one out of every five likely voters would not pick either major party candidate and instead selected options such as ""Other
column6: ""Wouldn't Vote"" or ""Refused."" That was twice the number of uncommitted voters as there were in the Reuters/Ipsos poll at the same point in 2012.

column1: Americans have expressed a dim view of both Clinton and Trump this year. Both candidates are disliked by a majority of likely voters
column2: according to the poll
column3: and an increasing number of women have expressed an ""unfavorable"" view of both candidates this week.In a separate poll that includes alternative-party candidates
column4: Clinton led the field by 5 percentage points. Among likely voters
column5: 42 percent supported Clinton
column6: 37 percent supported Trump
column7: 8 percent picked Libertarian candidate Gary Johnson and 2 percent supported Jill Stein of the Green Party.The Reuters/Ipsos poll is conducted online in English in all 50 states. The poll included 1
column8: 695 people who were considered likely voters due to their registration status
column9: voting history and stated intention to vote in the election. It has a credibility interval

column1: National opinion polls have differed this year in how they measure support for Clinton and Trump. Some polls
column2: like Reuters/Ipsos
column3: try to include only likely voters
column4: while others include all registered voters. The Reuters/Ipsos tracking poll also gathers responses every day and reports results twice a week
column5: so it often detects trends in sentiment before most other polls.An average of major opinion polls aggregated by RealClearPolitics showed Clinton ahead of Trump by 5 percentage points on Friday. (Editing by Jonathan Oatis)"	['Romney'
column6: 'Clinton'

column1: By Steve Holland and Michelle Conlin

WASHINGTON/NEW YORK Leaders of religious conservative groups largely stood behind Donald Trump on Saturday
column2: the day after vulgar sexual comments he made about women surfaced online
column3: but some expressed concern that the U.S. Republican presidential nominee's remarks could depress evangelical turnout on Election Day.Most evangelical leaders did not condemn Trump
column4: and instead pointed to an urgent need to prevent Democratic nominee Hillary Clinton from winning the presidency
column5: reshaping the Supreme Court and implementing liberal policies.The latest blow to Trump's campaign came after a 2005 video surfaced of the then-reality TV star talking on an open microphone about groping women and trying to seduce a married woman. Vice presidential running mate Mike Pence said he could not defend Trump's words.Gary Bauer
column6: chairman of the Campaign for Working Families
column7: said Trump's ""grossly inappropriate language"" does not change the choice facing the country in the Nov. 8 election and that ""I continue to support the Trump-Pence ticket.""""Hillary Clinton is committed to enacting policies that will erode religious liberty

column12: according to the Public Religion Research Institute
column13: and represent a crucial voting bloc Trump needs to win the presidency.They have long represented a pillar of support for Republicans. In 2004

column16: a Mormon who many evangelicals considered too moderate
column18: according to a report by the Pew Research Center.Support from evangelicals for Trump has been strong throughout his campaign
column19: even though it was only late in life that the New York businessman adopted their cause. Social conservatives flocked to his side over other deeply religious Republican presidential candidates

column8: I will vote for Donald Trump. I'm not excusing his behavior at all. It's disgusting

Still

column4: and whether he can convince Christians that he is a changed man
column5: Lane said.

column1: He already apologized and said he was wrong

column1: 2	2	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-cyber-russia-idUSKCN12729B	U.S. formally accuses Russian hackers of political cyber attacks	"
By Mark Hosenball
column2: Dustin Volz and Jonathan Landay

column1: | WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON The U.S. government for the first time on Friday formally accused Russia of a campaign of cyber attacks against Democratic Party organizations ahead of the Nov. 8 presidential election.""We believe
column2: based on the scope and sensitivity of these efforts
column3: that only Russia's senior-most officials could have authorized these activities
column4: a U.S. government statement said on Friday about hacking of political groups.""These thefts and disclosures are intended to interfere with the U.S. election process.""U.S. intelligence officials concluded weeks ago that the Russian government was conducting or orchestrating cyber attacks against the Democratic National Committee and the Democratic Congressional Campaign Committee
column5: possibly to disrupt or discredit the election
column6: in which Democrat Hillary Clinton faces Republican Donald Trump.A Kremlin spokesman called the U.S. allegations ""nonsense""
column7: the Interfax news agency reported. On Saturday
column8: the Russian Foreign Ministry said the U.S. accusations lacked any proof and were an attempt by Washington to fan ""unprecedented anti-Russian hysteria"".""This whipping up of emotions regarding 'Russian hackers' is used in the U.S. election campaign
column11: is not averse to using dirty tricks
column12: Deputy Foreign Minister Sergei Ryabkov said on Saturday in comments posted on the ministry's website.The Obama administration's decision to blame Russia for the attacks is the latest downward turn in U.S. relations with Moscow
column13: which are under strain over Russia's actions in Syria and Ukraine and in cyberspace.Also on Friday
column14: U.S. Secretary of State John Kerry said Russian and Syrian actions in the Syrian civil war
column16: ""beg for"" a war crimes investigation.In addition
column17: a U.S. intelligence official said on Friday that Russia was moving short-range nuclear-capable missiles into Kaliningrad
column18: a tiny Russian enclave between Poland and Lithuania

column1: Clinton's campaign chairman
column2: John Podesta
column3: said the public blaming for the hacks left one remaining question of ""why Donald Trump continues to make apologies for the Russians"". Trump had previously expressed doubt about Russia's involvement. In July
column4: he suggested Russia should attempt to retrieve and publish emails from Clinton's private server. Trump's campaign did not immediately respond to a request for comment.Hours after the U.S. government's accusation was levied
column5: WikiLeaks posted hundreds of emails on its website purportedly hacked from Podesta's private account.CHANGE IN TONE

column1: Until Friday
column2: the Obama administration had avoided publicly singling out Russia in connection with the mounting civilian deaths in Syria or the cyber attacks.The statement by the Department of Homeland Security and the Office of the Director of National Intelligence did not blame the Russian government for hacking attempts against state election systems
column3: but said ""scanning and probing"" of those systems originated in most cases from servers operated by a Russian company.However
column4: a Department of Homeland Security spokesman said U.S. officials had concluded that the hacking attacks or probes of state voter registration systems were ""consistent with Russian motivations"".Concern has grown about the reliability of the U.S. voting system as a result of the breach
column5: and Trump has called the system ""rigged
column6: but without providing specific evidence.U.S. intelligence officials have said there is no evidence that voting recording systems have been manipulated.

column1: Identifying Russia as the actor behind the cyber attacks on political organizations falls short of more punitive measures the United States has taken against other countries for cyber intrusions.    Lawmakers of both political parties welcomed the formal accusation. Republican Senator Cory Gardner
column2: chairman of the U.S. Senate Foreign Relations Subcommittee on East Asia
column3: the Pacific and International Cybersecurity
column4: said he planned to introduce sanctions legislation.Earlier this year
column5: a U.S. grand jury indicted seven Iranians employed by two Iran-based computer firms on charges of hacking into the U.S. financial sector. In 2015
column6: Obama announced sanctions against North Korea for hacking into Sony Pictures.In 2014
column7: the United States charged five Chinese military hackers for economic espionage aimed at U.S. nuclear
column8: metals and solar industries.A senior U.S. official said the administration is considering other retaliatory steps against Russia
column9: but he declined to identify them. Those steps may remain covert
column10: the official said.  The Democratic National Committee publicly disclosed intrusions into its systems in June and held Russia responsible. Leaks of committee emails from pro-transparency group WikiLeaks soon followed
column11: demonstrating what appeared to be favoritism for Clinton over another Democrat
column13: by committee chairwoman Debbie Wasserman Schultz. Wasserman Schultz
column16: the government said disclosures of emails by WikiLeaks and hacking entities known as DCLeaks and Guccifer 2.0 ""are consistent with the methods and motivations of Russian-directed efforts"". WikiLeaks has not identified the source of its leaks and criticized those who have claimed it was Russia. Guccifer 2.0 has identified itself as a Romanian hacker
column17: but U.S. intelligence officials have concluded that Guccifer 2.0 and DCLeaks are both a front for Russian spy units.    (Reporting by Mark Hosenball
column19: writing by Dustin Volz and Julia Edwards; Editing by Grant McCool and Mark Heinrich)"	['Schultz'

column1: 3	3	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-election-trump-transcript-idUSKCN12806S	Transcript of Trump video statement in response to lewd remarks about women	"

WASHINGTON U.S. Republican presidential nominee Donald Trump issued a video statement early on Saturday in response to the disclosure of a 2005 videotape of him making lewd remarks about women.Here is a text of his statement:
I've never said I'm a perfect person
column2: nor pretended to be someone that I'm not. I've said and done things I regret
column3: and the words released today on this more than a decade-old video are one of them. Anyone who knows me knows these words don't reflect who I am. I said it
column4: I was wrong and I apologize. I've traveled the country talking about change for America but my travels have also changed me. I've spent time with grieving mothers who have lost their children
column5: laid-off workers whose jobs have gone to other countries and people from all walks of life who just want a better future. I have gotten to know the great people of our country and I have been humbled by the faith they have placed in me. I pledge to be a better man tomorrow and will never
column6: ever let you down. Let's be honest. We're living in the real world. This is nothing more than a distraction from the important issues we're facing today. We're losing our jobs. We're less safe than we were eight years ago and Washington is totally broken. Hillary  Clinton and her kind have run our country into the ground. I've said some foolish things but there's a big difference between the words and actions of other people. Bill Clinton has actually abused women and Hillary has bullied
column8: shamed and intimidated his victims. We will discuss this more in the coming days. See you at the debate on Sunday.""

column1: By Valerie Volcovici
| WASHINGTON
WASHINGTON Democratic presidential hopeful Hillary Clinton struggled with how to secure the endorsement of labor unions while announcing her opposition to the Keystone XL oil pipeline
column2: a project they supported but environmentalists opposed
column3: according to leaked emails published by Wikileaks on Friday.Before announcing in September 2015 that she opposed TransCanada Corp's proposal to build a pipeline from Canada to the United States
column4: her campaign sought to ""soften the blow"" to labor unions by offering an energy infrastructure plan that would create jobs
column5: according to the emails. The internal campaign emails from August 2015 reveal the difficulty Clinton had in appeasing both unions and environmentalists as she fought for her party's nomination ahead of the Nov. 8 election.Wikileaks published the Clinton emails just hours after the U.S. government accused Russia of a campaign of cyber attacks against Democratic Party organizations.    In the emails
column6: Clinton advisers discussed how to frame the candidate's ""energy infrastructure"" plan
column7: which would call for replacing old pipelines
column8: repairing rail tracks and improving the electric grid in a way that would appeal to labor unions
column9: who had yet to endorse her at that stage.""Could we mention that ... as we transition HRC wants to create more careers within the new energy economy? Careers is their buzz word
column11: labor outreach director for Hillary for America.

column1: Clinton had long avoided taking a firm position on Keystone
column2: which had been pending for seven years
column3: as she sought her party's nomination last year. As secretary of state
column4: Clinton said in 2010 she was inclined to approve it. Rival Senator Bernie Sanders had been a staunch opponent of the pipeline. President Barack Obama did not reject the pipeline until November 2015.Labor unions have pushed for approval of the pipeline
column5: saying it would create thousands of construction jobs while environmentalists opposed it because it would increase greenhouse gas emissions from Canada's oil sands.The emails show that North America's Building Trades
column6: representing builders and construction workers
column7: contacted the campaign after hearing that Obama would announce his denial of the pipeline in late August and that Clinton would say she ""encouraged"" him to make the decision.

column1: We are so close to getting bldg (sic) trades [endorsement] and if we do this right

column4: the campaign's national political adviser.The Building Trades union endorsed Clinton in November and the Laborers' International Union of North America endorsed Clinton in December. Clinton's struggle to please both green and labor groups is likely to emerge as a key challenge if she is to win the presidency.

column2: the Dakota Access

column1: 6	6	http://reuters.com/article/us-volkswagen-emissions-idUSKCN12801C	Congresswoman raises concerns about VW settlement oversight	"
By Rory Carroll and David Shepardson
| SAN FRANCISCO/WASHINGTON
SAN FRANCISCO/WASHINGTON A settlement with U.S. regulators gives Volkswagen AG (VOWG_p.DE) too much authority over how to spend $2 billion on electric vehicle technology
column2: a U.S. congresswoman from California said this week in a letter
column3: echoing concerns from states and others who fear the German automaker gains undue influence in the deal.Volkswagen agreed to spend $1.2 billion nationally and $800 million more in California on electric vehicle technology as penalties for equipping hundreds of thousands of diesel vehicles sold in the United States with software designed to cheat tailpipe emissions tests.The letter from Representative Anne Eshoo comes ahead of an Oct. 18 hearing at which a federal judge will consider whether to give final approval to $15.3 billion in settlements for owners
column4: state and federal regulators or require changes and renegotiation.A provision ""of particular concern"" allows VW to make ""possible investments in its own proprietary technology and subsidiaries
column5: Eshoo
column6: a Democrat
column7: said in the Oct. 4 letter to Environmental Protection Agency (EPA) Administrator Lisa McCarthy.

column1: The EPA declined to comment. VW was not immediately available for comment. It has urged the court approve the deal.Eshoo's fears mirror those raised by electric car-charging station companies in August.
Four members of the California state legislature
column2: in comments to the U.S. Department of Justice
column3: also urged independent oversight and administration of the VW funds ""to ensure that multiple vendors with cutting-edge technology are able to enter the market."" The Justice Department said last month it received 1
column4: 195 comments period from private citizens
column5: state and local government offices and agencies
column6: businesses
column7: and institutions and associations. The DOJ urged the agreements be approved with only minor changes.

column1: Objectors face an uphill battle since U.S. courts generally give the government significant latitude to negotiate settlements. The Justice Department said nearly half of the comments were submitted on behalf of a company that provides truck-stop electrification services to long-haul truck drivers
column2: IdleAir

column1: 7	7	http://reuters.com/article/us-yahoo-nsa-order-idUSKCN12800D	U.S. pressed to disclose secret court's order on Yahoo email search	"
By Joseph Menn
| SAN FRANCISCO

SAN FRANCISCO A U.S. senator and civil groups critical of surveillance practices on Friday called on the government to release a 2015 order by a secret court directing Yahoo to scan all its users' incoming email
column2: saying it appeared to involve new interpretations of at least two important legal issues.Their concerns center on the nature of the technical assistance the court required Yahoo to provide and the scope of the search that legal experts said appeared to cover the Silicon Valley internet company's entire network.Yahoo installed a custom software program to search messages to hundreds of millions of accounts at the behest of U.S. intelligence officials with an order from the Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court
column3: a secret tribunal
column4: Reuters reported on Tuesday.They were looking for messages containing a single piece of digital content
column5: three former employees and a fourth person apprised of the events told Reuters.Intelligence officials told Reuters that all Yahoo had to do was modify existing systems for stopping child pornography from being sent through its email or filtering spam messages.But the pornography filters are aimed only at video and still images and cannot search text
column6: as the Yahoo program did. The spam filters
column8: are viewable by many employees who curate them
column9: and there is no confusion about where they sit in the software stack and how they operate.

column1: The court-ordered search Yahoo conducted
column2: on the other hand
column3: was done by a module attached to the Linux kernel - in other words
column4: it was deeply buried near the core of the email server operating system
column5: far below where mail sorting was handled
column6: according to three former Yahoo employees.They said that made it hard to detect and also made it hard to figure out what the program was doing. How much companies can be forced to do to comply with government orders for searching data is being debated in the courts. Companies have successfully argued that changes that would degrade users' experience or force them to write new code
column9: Apple refused to write code that would unlock an iPhone belonging to a gunman in last year's mass shooting in San Bernardino
column10: California. The FBI later dropped its demand.

column1: In the case of Yahoo
column2: company security staff discovered a software program that was scanning email but ended an investigation when they found it had been approved by Chief Executive Officer Marissa Mayer
column3: the sources said. Lawmakers are concerned about the request and whether information about it is being properly disclosed to the public.""Recent reports of a mass-email scanning program have alleged that federal law is being interpreted in ways that many Americans would find surprising and troubling
column4: said Democratic Senator Ron Wyden of Oregon
column5: a member of the intelligence committee and frequent critic of government surveillance programs.

column1: The USA Freedom Act requires the executive branch to declassify Foreign Intelligence Surveillance Court opinions that involve novel interpretations of laws or the Constitution
column2: Wyden said. Intelligence officials said the Yahoo order resembled other requests for monitoring online communications of suspected terrorists. The program is far different from the bulk collection of emails and telephone records that was disclosed by fugitive National Security Agency contractor Edward Snowden
column3: they said
column4: stressing the target was a digital ""signature"" associated with a single entity's suspected terrorist activity.But legal experts question whether the order might have stretched the concept of a ""facility"" used by a foreign power from its traditional definition
column5: involving a single phone number or an email account
column6: to include a large company's entire communication network.""If the facility means all of Yahoo's network
column7: I don't see how that's consistent with the Fourth Amendment
column10: senior counsel at the Center for Democracy & Technology. (Reporting by Joseph Menn and John Walcott; Additional reporting by Dustin Volz and Mark Hosenball; editing by Jonathan Weber and Grant McCool)"	['Wyden'

column1: 8	8	http://reuters.com/article/us-usa-myanmar-sanctions-idUSKCN127262	Obama announces lifting of U.S. sanctions on Myanmar	"
By David Brunnstrom
| WASHINGTON

WASHINGTON President Barack Obama formally announced the lifting of U.S. sanctions on Myanmar on Friday by terminating an emergency order that deemed the policies of the former military government a threat to U.S. national security.""I have determined that the situation that gave rise to the national emergency ... has been significantly altered by Burma's (Myanmar's) substantial advances to promote democracy
column2: including historic elections in November 2015
column3: Obama said in a letter to the U.S. House and Senate speakers.A U.S. Treasury statement said that as a result of the termination of the emergency order the economic and financial sanctions administered by the Department of the Treasury's Office of Foreign Assets Control were no longer in effect.The move followed a meeting between Myanmar's de facto leader Aung San Suu Kyi and Obama in Washington last month
column4: when she called for the lifting of economic sanctions against her country
column5: and he said he was willing to do this.Suu Kyi's National League for Democracy won a sweeping victory in the November elections.

column1: Obama's letter pointed to the formation of a democratically elected
column2: civilian-led government as a result of the election
column3: the release of many political prisoners and improved human rights and fundamental freedoms
column4: including freedom of expression and freedom of association and peaceful assembly.""While Burma faces significant challenges
column5: including the consolidation of its democracy
column6: the United States can
column8: use other means to support the government and people of Burma in their efforts to address these challenges
column10: a Nobel Peace Prize laureate and democracy icon
column11: helped persuade the West to impose sanctions on Myanmar
column12: which is also known as Burma
column13: during her years as a jailed opposition leader. She is now trying to strike a balance between showing her people the economic rewards of a democratic transition while keeping pressure on the country's generals for further reforms.

column1: Some members of the U.S. Congress have expressed concerns about the extent and durability of change in Myanmar and introduced legislation seeking to give lawmakers some influence on the process of easing sanctions.Rights groups condemned last month's announcement
column2: saying it  forfeited leverage on Myanmar's military.

column1: Officials of the U.S. administration have said the removal of sanctions would not apply to military-to-military assistance
column2: given the extent of the military's involvement in politics and rights abuses.Suu Kyi herself has been criticized for doing too little to address the plight of Myanmar's stateless Rohingya Muslim  minority.The State Department said last month that several restrictions would remain in place
column3: including barring visas for military leaders. (Reporting by David Brunnstrom; Editing by Eric Walsh and Cynthia Osterman)"	['Obama']	[]
